channel.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
channel.description:
Just like when all the dinosaurs died.
The black hole in the galaxy is gonna send a massive wave of energy in the earths axis & the earth will lose its levitation & gravity Everything will shift & kill us all.
[IMG]http://i37.tinypic.com/28ba4o5.jpg[/img]

item.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Jamie1200:

[quote]When we can’t see the sun, the orbit of Earth no longer exists, and we go hurdling off into space.

No…It’s night time fool.[/quote]Ok. When we can’t see the sun’s light, THEN we go hurdling off into space :3

Read full topic

item.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

rip4d:

Einstein’s theory of gravity was that the more mass an object had, the bigger of a bevel it put in the fabric of space time (imagine it as stepping on a trampoline). In that bevel, the planets spin around it and create their own dent for smaller object to orbit. Take for example the sun. If it were to suddenly disappear, its bevel would ripple like a wave along with the light the sun was creating. When we can’t see the sun’s light anymore, Earth is then thrown out of its orbit in whichever direction it was already headed in.

Exactly, its a theory. I could believe that or the opposite and it wouldn’t change what gravity is. So arguing is pointless.

Read full topic
item.source: Were all gunna die still in 2012

item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:79, topic:334610”]Einstein’s theory of gravity was that the more mass an object had, the bigger of a bevel it put in the fabric of space time (imagine it as stepping on a trampoline). In that bevel, the planets spin around it and create their own dent for smaller object to orbit. Take for example the sun. If it were to suddenly disappear, its bevel would ripple like a wave along with the light the sun was creating. When we can’t see the sun’s light anymore, Earth is then thrown out of its orbit in whichever direction it was already headed in.[/quote]The theory was that the fabric of space time was like any normal fabric, and the greater the objects mass the more of a dent it put into it. I think that’s bull shit.

Read full topic

item.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:77, topic:334610”][quote author=Frell link=topic=431007.msg3165826#msg3165826 date=1269998102]es. If Newtonian physics and relativistic physics are in a sense “ways” to look at physics, then this argument does not matter. It can be opinionated either way as we are only discussing theories/laws.
[/quote]
Newtonian physics was an earlier theorization of physics formed mostly by, you guessed it, Isaac Newton (Namely his famous “Three laws”). Relativistic physics is a more accurate formulation that was developed several hundred years later by Einstein. It contains a lot of freaky shit; but it’s the theory that’s most in agreement with current experimental data. The main differences between relativistic physics and newtonian physics are for objects moving near the speed of light (For objects moving comparably slower, relativistic physics more or less reduces to newtonian physics).
The reason that you are a moron is that you think gravity gravity does not “move” while having nothing to base it on other than thinking you would be dumb if you believed it did. You also amply demonstrate your inability to comprehend language with such gems of mental inactivity as “Its an ‘it’ not a thing.”

You may find this very interesting: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_wave[/quote]

Predicted by Einstein's theory of general relativity, the waves tra...
So then its opinionated, you could look at it either way and argue with the opposing.

Read full topic
item.source: Were all gunna die still in 2012

item.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Frell:

es. If Newtonian physics and relativistic physics are in a sense “ways” to look at physics, then this argument does not matter. It can be opinionated either way as we are only discussing theories/laws.

Newtonian physics was an earlier theorization of physics formed mostly by, you guessed it, Isaac Newton (Namely his famous “Three laws”). Relativistic physics is a more accurate formulation that was developed several hundred years later by Einstein. It contains a lot of freaky shit; but it’s the theory that’s most in agreement with current experimental data. The main differences between relativistic physics and newtonian physics are for objects moving near the speed of light (For objects moving comparably slower, relativistic physics more or less reduces to newtonian physics).
The reason that you are a moron is that you think gravity gravity does not “move” while having nothing to base it on other than thinking you would be dumb if you believed it did. You also amply demonstrate your inability to comprehend language with such gems of mental inactivity as “Its an ‘it’ not a thing.”

You may find this very interesting: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitational_wave

Read full topic
item.source: Were all gunna die still in 2012

item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

Frell:

Gravity is how we refer to the force itself. It cant move, gravity is just gravity. You can’t pass your hand through gravity and feel it and you cant see it. Its an ‘it’ not a thing.

I’m pretty sure force is a ‘thing’, but then again, it all depends on how you define a ‘thing’.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Frell wrote:

lol’d so hard. You can feel light, you can see light. The phrase “speed of light” infers that light can actually move, which we all know it does. As soon as i can touch gravity, see it, and watch it move ill believe you.

ps i love how you really had nothing to say so you filled in gaps with etc etc.

I do not know alot about physics, but im not dumb enough to think gravity moves. If Newtonian physics and relativistic physics are in a sense “ways” to look at physics, then this argument does not matter. It can be opinionated either way as we are only discussing theories/laws.

item.title: Were all gunna die still in 2012
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Frell:

Nope, just another person who doesn’t know what they’re talking about.

I will now quote as many of your posts in this thread that evidence you being a fucktard as my mind can take (And post size limits permit):

[quote=“Frell, post:66, topic:334610”]Gravity is how we refer to the force itself. It cant move, gravity is just gravity. You can’t pass your hand through gravity and feel it and you cant see it. Its an ‘it’ not a thing.[/quote]True in newtonian physics (Somewhat), false in relativistic physics

[quote=“Frell, post:25, topic:334610”]Gravity is a force… It cant move at any speed.[/quote]ditto the above

[quote=“Frell, post:29, topic:334610”]It pushes.

Light is light, you can see and feel light (form of heat), so it can actually move. This means it can move at the speed of light (duh). You can’t see gravity or feel it. You can feel effects from it but not gravity itself, therefore gravity isnt a thing and cant move. So it cant travel at the speed of light, or anything for that matter.[/quote]this is at best the product of brain damage that would be fatal to any other life form than yourself; light is a form of electromagnetic radiation, you imply that gravity can’t do anything but we can somehow observe it’s effects, etc etc just stop posting

Read full topic
item.source: Were all gunna die still in 2012
